items.content_html:
Now you can customize the look and feel of Ally on iOS and macOS with three themes.

Newspaper theme
Newspaper is a grayscale monochrome theme for people who like light themes. It has a near white background, containers and fields are shades of gray, and text is near black gray.

Monochrome theme
For dark theme lovers, monochrome has a near black background, dark container backgrounds, and near white text.

Primary theme
My personal favorite, Primary is a low contrast theme with a brown background, green highlights, a text is shades of cream-colored off whites. The theme for those who like a bit of color.

This is just the beginning... what other themes would you like to see? What fonts would you like Ally to support?

items.content_html:
One of the core goals of Ally as a productivity solution is ensuring communication with Ally is fast and easy. You should be able to add a todo, capture an idea, or get the date of your next meeting without friction.

There’s no faster way to capture quick thoughts, reminders, and notes than with dictation and there’s no faster way to start dictation than with the iPhone Action button, a configurable hardware button on 14, 15, 16, and 17 series iPhones.

The iOS app was recently updated to include an Action button shortcut that instantly opens the Ally AI iOS app and starts a recording.

This means you can capture any thought instantly any time your phone is near with just a single click. It’s the fastest, most frictionless way to pass information from your head to Ally where it can be organized and retrieved when needed.

It’s a great way to get things out of your head and into your Ally Inbox where you can then store, organize, and leverage it in the future.

How to configure your iPhone’s Action button to quickly capture and transcribe voice notes:

  1. Install the Ally AI iOS app from the iOS app store.

  2. Open the Settings app on your iPhone.

  3. Scroll down to find Action Button in the list and tap it to open its options.

  4. Swipe right to left to scroll through the options until you reach Shortcut.

  5. Press the selector and search the available shortcuts for Ally.

  6. Choose Start Recording by pressing it.

  7. Close the Settings app.

  8. Press and hold the Action button on your phone to do a test recording.

Being able to quickly capture voice notes is like a super power. You can get things out of your head and into a productivity system with minimal friction and get back to whatever needs your attention.

items.content_html:
Markdown editors are a personal thing. For me, my priorities are:

  1. Fast: I should be able to launch it and create a new document near instantly.
  2. Beautiful: Markdown text should render nicely.
  3. Simple: The tool should get out of your way so you can focus on productivity.

iA Writer

One of the originals, and still one of the best, for anyone looking for a lightweight, document-focused editing experience. It’s refined, elegant, and it does its job well. So, it’s no surprise it’s been the go-to mac app for Markdown editing for over a decade now.

iA Writer integrates a simple file management solution that may be adequate for most users, but may not be enough for power users trying to create a productivity system or PKM style “second brain.” Those users may be more interested in something like Obsidian…

Obsidian

No list of markdown editors would be complete without the undisputed king of robust markdown editing. If you’re looking for a markdown editing experience that can become a full productivity system, then you’ll find no peer. It has a massive library of community created plugins for pretty much anything.

Note that Obsidian’s strength is also its curse. Some users find the complexity created by its near limitless configuration options overwhelming. Some find that they end up spending more time maintaining their Obsidian-based productivity system than they do actually being productive.

Typora

Typora is often compared to iA Writer with good reason. They’re both minimalistic and simple. To highlight the major difference, I’d say that Typora is more focused on advanced editing capabilities while iA Writer seeks to be a more simplified experience to keep you creative and productive. In other words, if you need advanced markdown features like math/diagram support, then Typora may be your best option.

Bear

When Bear came onto the scene, it redefined elegance for iOS and macOS productivity apps. Its tag-first approach to organizing notes remains unique and one of the most flexible ways to organize a large library of notes.

Where some users may want more is around advanced personal knowledge management (PKM) and automation features. In that case, you’re looking to build a sophisticated productivity system, something like Obsidian may be a better fit.

I have a hard time criticizing it, it’s my favorite macOS app of all time, and a huge inspiration for…

Ally

A new comer, what makes Ally unique is its unique local AI-first approach to knowledge management and AI collaboration.

There’s no separation between your Markdown docs and what the AI “sees” so you can quickly switch back and forth between editing/creation and an AI that’s always in sync. It also offers a uniquely flexible node system where nodes are simulateously markdown docs, folders, and chats so you can add new nodes without wasting any resources on whether you need a folder, doc, or chat.

items.title: Ally macOS app gets native full screen mode support

items.content_html:
Long periods of unbroken concentration, that most of us require to achieve the deep focus that leads to “deep work,” are increasingly challenging to come by.

We know our best work comes from focus, but it can be challenging to tailor our digital workspaces to minimize distractions. Even on macOS, an operating system built for the desktop/laptop format, and so tailored toward productivity, work, and creation, they’re, at least in some ways, intentionally designed to divert our attention away from whatever we’re trying to do, such as for alerts and notifications. There’s also a row of colorful icons tempting us to stray from our intended focus.

macOS’s full-screen mode helps with focus and concentration, thereby improving our ability to achieve the flow state many of us need to do our best work. It simply minimizes distracting visual clutter by devoting the entire screen to a single app. This is an app experience that’s default behavior on Windows, but not macOS. Both modes have their uses and benefits, so it doesn’t really make sense to frame it as a “right or wrong” debate.

But, for deep work, work that requires prolonged intense focus to be productive, many of us benefit from minimal distraction, and things like macOS’s full-screen mode help a lot by massively trimming distracting and potentially overwhelming visual noise. For anyone closer to the challenging end of the attention spectrum, the “multi-task mode” that macOS encourages by default can actually be a sneaky productivity killer. It can feel like we’re getting a lot done, but we’re really shuffling around windows and never really delving deep enough into any particular thing to solve a complex problem, come up with a great new idea, or uncover important nuance in a data set.

Now Ally supports full-screen mode so you can laser focus on whatever doc you’re creating, web clipping you’re reading, or AI chat you’re having.

To get started, download the latest version of the Ally AI app from the macOS app store.

With the Ally app running, press the key combination fn + f or click the green circle icon in the upper left-hand corner of the app.

To exit full screen mode, you can press esc, fn + f again, or click the green circle icon that appears when you hover the upper left-hand corner of the app while in full screen mode.

You can also arrange the Ally app side by side with other apps, such as a web browser or PDF viewer, by clicking and holding the green circle icon, then selecting one of the tile options to arrange the window.

Now you can focus better with fewer visual distractions competing for your attention.

I’ll continue looking for new ways to leverage Apple’s ecosystem to make productivity easier with Ally. If you have an idea, let me know or submit as a feature request and I’ll add it to the community-driven roadmap.
